TEMPLATE_RIGHT_TO_INFORMATION.description: Specialized template for Right to Information

components.text: Right to Information About Your Treatment
**Legal Reference:** {citation_format}

You have the right to receive clear information about:
• Your diagnosis and condition
• Proposed tests and treatments
• Possible risks and complications
• Expected costs and payment details
• Identity of your healthcare providers

**Your Doctor/Hospital Must:**
• Explain in language you understand
• Provide cost information in writing
• Give itemized bills upon request
• Identify themselves properly

**What You Can Do:**
1. Ask specific questions about your treatment
2. Request written cost estimates
3. Ask for explanation of any medical terms you don't understand
4. Request identification of all healthcare providers

TEMPLATE_RIGHT_TO_RECORDS.description: Specialized template for Right to Medical Records

components.text: Right to Access Your Medical Records
**Legal Reference:** {citation_format}

You have the right to get copies of your medical documents including:
• Case papers and treatment records
• Test results and investigation reports
• Discharge summary
• Itemized bills

**Important Timeframes:**
• During admission: Preferably within 24 hours
• After discharge: Within 72 hours

**Hospital Must:**
• Provide records within specified time
• Allow photocopying at reasonable cost
• Give death summary to relatives if applicable

**What You Can Do:**
1. Submit a written request for records
2. Note the date of your request
3. Follow up if records aren't provided within 72 hours
4. Pay only reasonable photocopying charges
Right to Informed Consent Before Procedures
**Legal Reference:** {citation_format}

For any risky or invasive procedure (surgery, chemotherapy, etc.), you must be:
• Fully informed about risks and benefits
• Given alternative options
• Asked for written permission before proceeding

**Doctor Must:**
• Explain main risks in understandable language
• Obtain written consent before procedure
• Provide consent forms with proper protocols

**Exceptions (consent not required):**
• Life-threatening emergencies when patient is unconscious
• Certain legal requirements

**What You Can Do:**
1. Ask questions until you fully understand
2. Don't sign if you're unsure or pressured
3. Request time to think if needed
4. Keep a copy of signed consent forms

TEMPLATE_RIGHT_TO_EMERGENCY_CARE.description: Specialized template for Emergency Care rights

components.text: Right to Emergency Medical Care
**Legal Reference:** {citation_format}

All hospitals (government and private) must provide emergency care:
• Without demanding advance payment
• Regardless of patient's ability to pay
• Promptly and without delay

**Hospital Must:**
• Start emergency treatment immediately
• Not ask for payment before stabilizing patient
• Maintain quality and safety standards

**What You Can Do:**
1. Go directly to nearest hospital in emergency
2. Insist on immediate stabilization
3. Report any hospital demanding advance payment
4. Know this is protected by Supreme Court orders
Right to Privacy and Confidentiality
**Legal Reference:** {citation_format}

Your medical information must be kept private and confidential:
• Doctors cannot share your health details without permission
• Female patients can request female attendant during exams
• Medical data must be securely stored

**Healthcare Providers Must:**
• Keep patient information confidential
• Ensure data security against leaks/theft
• Provide female attendant if requested

**Exceptions (when disclosure allowed):**
• Required by law (court orders)
• Public health emergencies
• To protect others from serious harm

**What You Can Do:**
1. Ask who has access to your medical information
2. Request female attendant during examinations if needed
3. Report any unauthorized sharing of your information
4. Inquire about data security measures
